body: Thanks for this catch.

Ingestion with UTC is nice, what you care about maybe more likely related to query side. [Granularity Doc](http://druid.io/docs/latest/querying/granularities.html) mentioned that 

``` json
   "granularity":{"type": "period", "period": "P1D", "timeZone": "America/Los_Angeles", "origin": "1970-01-01T20:30:00-08:00"}
```
Thanks @jaebinyo ! Would you mind filling out http://druid.io/community/cla.html ?
i don't see any UTs for eviction especially for the custom made weight function.
@himanshug / @xvrl Was tinkering with how to do assignments. I was hoping I could tag both of you as commenters here. Turns out I can only tag 1
@fjy / @himanshug any more comments here?

@himanshug sorry for taking so long to reply, this approach in #2109 does sound good to me though.

Is there an existing endpoint on the overlord/coordinator that gets the list of segments from the metadata store for an interval? Or do we need to add that?
Weird, says there's a failure but travis logs state all tests passed...
@b-slim is there anything beyond syntactic sugar you foresee `LookupDimensionSpec` being able to help with? (as opposed to using a dimension extraction specification, for example)

@drcrallen 
1. First Lookup is more generic than Extraction function by definition 
2. Second it is preferable to avoid nesting Json object if it is possible to do it
3. Finally it will be easier to do optimization since testing for actual lookup will be one instruction instead of having multiple if/else.
I filled out the form and submitted.

> First Lookup is more generic than Extraction function by definition

how so?
Cool thanks! :+1:

> how so?

@drcrallen Lookup exposes unapply while extraction function not ....

@b-slim ok then you need to say that and not just "by definition". 

The result is that extraction function was never intended to have an unapply while lookups can.

As such a lookup extractor can serve as an extraction function, but an extraction function cannot serve as a lookup.

The rest is syntactic sugar (and nice syntactic sugar).
It should also be possible to have a dimension extraction bridge which takes the parameter "unapply":boolean and can work at the dimension extractor level, but without any unapply optimization.
@salsakran Yay! Thanks for the contrib. Do you mind filling out druid.io/community/cla.html and I'll merge this

done!

@xvrl any chance you can +1 this PR if you think it is ready?
@b-slim nothing in particular. Just want to be able to graph all of the metrics available here http://druid.io/docs/latest/operations/metrics.html per host.
@b-slim is the code for this available anywhere? I have pretty urgent need for this feature, so I would otherwise start writing something myself.
@CHOIJAEHONG1 why are you creating v8 segments?
@xvrl any more comments?
@fjy Actually, I don't have any reason using v8 segments. But I just found it while I was reading the codebase and thought that it would be better fixed.
Wishfully include an UT
@xvrl , no , i will change it, and update the patch.

Hi Fangjin,
I am working with our legal team to get CLA and hoping I will get in 1-2 days.
Thanks,
Ruchir

@pjain1 @rasahner @himanshug @navis @gianm 

This is no longer WIP and is ready to be merged. There are lots of changes to the docs and distribution.

@drcrallen thanks for review, I will probably rework this a bit after https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2085 is merged.
we have very high memory brokers and don't usually need swap at all. this PR is intended to avoid GC pauses really. at historicals, we have some subsets where more segments than available memory are loaded, but we have SSDs there and it works ok.

also, I do not want to block 0.9.0 RC because of this so setting the milestone for this to be 0.9.1
However, I will pull it in my internal distribution as soon as it is merged.

@binlijin looks like tests are failing right now. If the IntBox is not any faster than AtomicInteger, then let's keep it simple and stick to AtomicInteger

+1 once travis passes and once we know which one is faster.
Test with IntBox the average time is **4440** ms
ok I'm fine with either one, it's hard to tell if the difference is statistically significant without knowing any standard deviation.
@guobingkun @drcrallen: Since you are working on similar area, Can you guys do the initial review and provide feedback ?

@himanshug we don't have to get held up by the non-ascii stuff, but I feel having a header that might either be incomplete or mangled will have to be addressed at some point.

+1 once we file an issue about the non-ascii mangling in reponse context
noted in dev-sync on 2016-02-02 that it should just be deleted or made a NOOP for this release
@gianm is this an 0.9 regression with v9 indexing?
@himanshug @fjy : can you have a look ?
Added Release Notes label to note that we removed the convertProperties in 0.9
@xvrl this is a pre-existing bug, it was reported on the forums: https://groups.google.com/d/topic/druid-user/Q1IxjMtAtEw/discussion
@nishantmonu51 is this mentioned somewhere in the documentation? then we might need to remove there as well.
I don't see any mention of "convertProps" in the docs, so :+1:
@himanshug: did a quick search in docs, could not find it mentioned in docs.
@gianm gzipped the file so it should be easier to read this PR
@xvrl tracking in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/2372
having '/' in metric name is interesting, I believe we should put restriction on the set of characters allowed in the metric/dimension names.

@CHOIJAEHONG1 thanks for looking around.   However, I don't think v8 segment format ever included support for long type columns, so there shouldn't be any v8 segment out there which has a long type column stored in it. LegacyIndexLoader is doing the right thing actually, it was never meant to support long on a v8 segment.
A lot of places seem to be implementing ListenableFutures by hand. Is it reasonable to change the callback stuff to be ListenableFutrue callbacks?
@navis have you guys tested this code in a production setting?
@himanshug addressed comments
@gianm FYI this came up during tranquility tests when hacking around with druid versions. Haven't validated this fixes the tests yet though (since tranquility uses logback instead of log4j)
fix in master
:+1: after travis
@himanshug Yes, but it's not look good and this kind of issue will be made periodically. How about just adding this?
@himanshug we good to go?
Also i think this use less memory.
@navis numbers look pretty good. I am :+1: after https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2085/files#r51679583 is resolved and commits are squashed.
@navis we can merge after @himanshug's last comment is addressed and commits are squashed
I'm setting the milestone on this one to be 0.9.0 as this is a bug with simple fix and should be released as early as possible.
@navis any benchmarks?
@nishantmonu51 Someone wanted me to group-by two non-identical but similar datasources. I think it cannot be handled by union-datasource.

@b-slim submitted PR https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2384
@michaelschiff without filters, druid will emit a huge number of metrics and that won't scale with a ganglia architecture. I would recommend that you use similar approach to graphite emitter.

:+1: 

@himanshug I don't see the extra UTs but I'm ok to merge without them at your discretion.

@b-slim I am not sure I agree with you about the filters. I do not see storing this quantity of metrics as a problem for ganglia.  Storing large quantities of metrics is the problem Ganglia is solving. I don't think it should be the concern of the emitter.  I think the emitter's job is to emit whatever metrics are collected.  Further, druid already has a mechanism for selecting which metrics you care about:
`druid.monitoring.monitors=["com.metamx.metrics.JvmMonitor", "io.druid.client.cache.CacheMonitor", "io.druid.server.metrics.HistoricalMetricsMonitor"]`

@michaelschiff can you point me to a documentation or implementation that shows how ganglia deals with very high cardinality dimensions ? I really think without filtering this won't work in production.
@michaelschiff need to add UTs as well please see the contributor guide.
@b-slim it looks like the `emit` here is not actually emitting any of the dimensions other than service, metric name, timestamp, and host. So ganglia should be able to handle that.

I am not including metric dimensions, just service name and metric name.  Including things like dimension would indeed blow up the number of individual metrics, and seems to be a more granular than can be supported by a system like Ganglia.

http://druid.io/docs/latest/operations/metrics.html

graphing a metric like `query/segment/time` per host seems sufficient.  I dont see the reason to include dimesions (like segment id) when there are possibly hundreds of thousands of segments in the cluster. If I am going to filter, its assumed I know which dimension values I care about in advance: How can I possibly know before hand which I am interested in?
Further, if we are talking about implementing identical filtering in each of these extensions, doesn't it make more sense to do this filtering one step up?

@michaelschiff  i am not sure i am getting this, if you emit only metric name how does ganglia handle aggregation ? does it collapse metrics by timestamp bucketing ? The other question what is the meaning of having let say 'query/time' of groupeBy and TopN as the something.
@gianm what is the meaning of emitting without dimensions ? what kind of insight or analytic you can draw from such information ? i am not sure i am getting this.
@drcrallen thanks, added tests.

@b-slim even without dimensions, some of the metrics are still useful. e.g. seeing really broad things like average query time, 90%ile query time, jvm heap use, realtime ingest rates, &c. You wouldn't be able to drill down by datasource or query type or anything like that though.

I am not really sure how ganglia aggregates these in practice though. For stuff like query/time in particular, Druid will emit lots of those for each query, and ganglia would have to aggregate them somehow. @michaelschiff any idea how ganglia will handle that?
@b-slim @gianm checking on how aggregation is handled now. As is, I think the PR will not do any aggregation, which I agree is not what we want.

Regarding the value of metrics w/o dimensions, I agree with @gianm, Many of these metrics have use without dimensions.  Storing the full dimensions in ganglia is definitely not feasible for the full set, but I dont think filtering on dimensions is the right approach. Yes it might make sense for some dimension (like you mention, queryType) but it does not for others (e.g. segment ids).  I think the inability to sum over high cardinality dimensions is just indicative of Ganglia's flaws, and highlights the advantage of using something like Druid for storing Druid metrics :P
